items.content_html:
Fixes #36974.

Per #36974 (comment), although this API does exist in Firefox, the documentation doesn't really explain what it does, and it's hard to see what it could be doing in web content. Would welcome a second opinion but I'm not sure this is still relevant.

items.content_html:
Description

In the docs for the various MouseEvents and PointerEvents, rarely do either mention the other. I added cross links, and also some discussions in various event pages how the moouse/pointer event differs from the corresponding pointer/mouse event.

I added notes to the over/out events, explaining how they're rarely used, and one should use the enter/leave events. (The details were explained already, but nowhere did I find it specifically say to not use over/out.)

I also did some other updates that I thought were needed.

Motivation

I only recently learned about pointer events, despite being a web developer for 10+ years. Maybe a few more links between pointer and mouse events would have helped me find out about them.

I saw a question recently about over/out events on StackOverflow, and sure enough, the questioner was using over/out when they should have used enter/leave. Probably others are in the same situation; sometimes you have to come out and say it.

Additional details

The pointer events
article introduction describes the situation pretty well.
(Do not confuse with the PointerEvent article, which describes the superclass.)

Related issues and pull requests

Fixes #27878
items.title: mouse & pointer event pages updates

items.content_html:
Description

Front matter linting looks like it uses main config instead of the branch because of execution context (even though front-matter-config.json is changed on the PR branch).

For a Learn area move, I would add a new slug entry Learn_web_development to main so that CI uses this config.

When the Learn area move is done, we can remove the ^Learn/ path from checks.

Motivation

Fixing failing CI in https://github.com/mdn/content/actions/runs/12027470524
items.title: chore(tests): Add 'Learn_web_development' slugs for front matter linter

items.content_html:
Description

Using custom elements page: make Safari implementation stance of customized built-in elements clear

Motivation

The previous text was very opaque for an introductory page meant to make people familiar with custom elements:

  • not clear what the is attribute is and why I should care as the reader at that point
  • not clear that a major browser is never going to implement this (it sounded more like implementation is just not finished yet)

Additional details

I would also be in favour of moving "customized built-in elements" to its own subsection instead of starting this page with the big heading "Types of custom elements", if in reality most people will only ever implement or encounter one of the types, because the other one is not going to be supported by Safari and might eventually be replaced with something else.

If people here agree, I can make a separate PR for that?
items.title: Using custom elements: make Safari implementation stance clear

items.content_html:
FF134 adds support for the HTML autocorrect attribute and HTMLElement.autocorrect property in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1725806#c19

This updates the docs to make it clear that while the mechanism for enabling autocorrection is specified, the underlying implementation depends on the user agent and its integration with native services.
That's a bit of a pain for the example, because I can't get this to work on Windows desktop, presumably because it doesn't have appropriate substitutions. It does work on MacOS. I can't test it on Android because there is no nightly release there on browserstack.

Related docs work can be tracked in #36919
items.title: HTML autocorrect - clarify device-specific subsitutions

items.content_html:
FF134 only supports Intl.DurationFormat in Nightly, as per https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1648139#c19.

This corrects my earlier PR #36959. Note that was impossible (for me) to tell it was supported only in nightly as there is no preference or other indication.

Related docs work can be tracked in #36917
items.title: FF134 Intl.Duration in Nightly only - expr/relnote

items.content_html:
FF134 supports PushManager/supportedContentEncodings() in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1497430

This attempts to provide a little more information on the usage of the API. I mean it is easy to see how this API is used, but not what you'd do with the returned information. I'm querying in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1497430#c12

Related docs work can be tracked in #36922

items.content_html:
Description

Motivation

Chrome supports extensions to the Screen Capture API that allow developers to limit the region of the capture. Namely, these are:

  • The Element Capture API, which is supported from Chrome 132 (see https://chromestatus.com/feature/5198989277790208).
  • The Region Capture API, which is supported from Chrome 104 (see https://chromestatus.com/feature/5712447794053120).

This PR adds documentation for these extensions under a new tree "Screen Capture extensions", which I felt was preferable to adding a separate docs tree for multiple APIs that do very similar things.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests

Fixes mdn/mdn#580

  • BCD addition: mdn/browser-compat-data#25232.
  • dom-examples addition: mdn/dom-examples#285. The linked demos won't work until this PR is merged.
items.title: Add documentation for Screen Capture extensions, element capture and region capture
